As of February 15th, 2024, you will no longer be able to create security advisories in private repositories. Formerly published advisories will no longer be available. This change does not affect security advisories in public repositories, or the advisories listed in GitHub’s open-source Advisory Database.
The post Deprecation notice: security advisories in private repositories appeared first on The GitHub Blog.
articles.title: Deprecation notice: security advisories in private repositories

articles.author: Christian Heusel
articles.description:
We are happy to announce that the migration of the bugtracker to GitLab is done! 🥳 
Thanks to everyone who has helped during the migration!
This means the issue tracker and merge requests on the GitLab package repos are now enabled.
The old bugtracker will subsequently be closed down. For archiving reasons there will be a static copy so that links (for example the randomly picked Task #56716) are still stable, migrated bugs have a closing comment pointing to the new URL on GitLab.
Packaging bugs are now opened on the repo hosting the corresponding packaging sources, the "Add a new Bug" button on the package page on archlinux.org will automatically direct you to the correct place to open the issue. The workflow afterwards is mostly the same, first our Bug Wranglers will have a look at the issues and triage them, and then they will be handed over to the respective Package Maintainers to fix. A list of all issues can be found here.
If you do not have an account for GitLab already (which authenticates against our SSO service), please write us a mail with your desired username to accountsupport@archlinux.org as advised in the banner.
articles.title: Bugtracker migration to GitLab completed

articles.author: Tom MacWright
articles.description:
I saw Tim Hecker at Pioneer Works, and was astounded by the opener, Mizu.
Bought the album as soon as I got home. It is, crudely explained, like if
Zoë Keating dialed up the synths and pedals and rhythm, and it was also a
remarkable live show.
Distant Intervals by MIZU

Reading
I love shopping! I do. I love commerce — the dance of it, the etiquette. I love it as buyer and seller both. I love considering alternatives, and I love being considered. I love settling on favorites. I love stumbling across surprises.
Am I simply bourgeois? Yes, and I’ll wave that flag proudly. This is a big part of my politics: which is not a politics of “free markets” or “free trade”, but rather of systems that can support commerce and craft at every level, especially the smallest and most careful.
From Robin Slo…
articles.title: Recently

sources.title: dotnet Archives - The New Dev's Guide

articles.description: We need to pay more attention to the physical impacts of mental illness. It could not only be messing with your mind, but also your heart, say scientists.
articles.title: Mental illness plays havoc with the mind as well as the heart

articles.description: A new study shows that young adults when sleep-deprived evaluate angry faces as less trustworthy and healthy-looking. Furthermore, neutral and fearful faces appear less attractive following sleep loss.
articles.title: Acute sleep loss may alter the way we see others

articles.description: Scientists pinpoint the molecular epicenter of deep-sleep regulation. The findings, based on research in mice, identify a gene that makes a protein that regulates delta waves -- electrical signals between neurons that occur during the deepest phases of relaxation and are a hallmark of restorative sleep.
articles.title: Molecular basis of deep sleep pinpointed, suggests avenues for novel treatments

articles.description: Researchers presents a new study demonstrating that a small molecule in brain cells affects the level of hypocretin, which is responsible for making us feel awake during the day and tired at night. People with a genetic variation of this molecule have a higher risk of suffering from daytime sleepiness.
articles.title: New sleep molecule discovered: 'It shows just how complex the machinery of sleep is'

articles.description: Seven hours is the ideal amount of sleep for people in their middle age and upwards, with too little or too much little sleep associated with poorer cognitive performance and mental health, say researchers.
articles.title: Seven hours of sleep is optimal in middle and old age, say researchers

articles.description: Up to half of older adults may have sleep apnea, a condition in which breathing and sleep are briefly interrupted many times a night. A new study shows that this chronic tiredness can have serious implications for road safety.
articles.title: Risky driving behaviors increase as common sleep disorder worsens

articles.description: Black women are disproportionately affected by poor sleep, which is associated with increased risk of adverse outcomes such as cardiovascular disease, depression and worse quality of life. The gold standard treatment for insomnia is cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), which specifically targets the individual's problematic sleep behaviors and beliefs.
articles.title: Automated cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia delivered over the internet shown to be highly effective in Black women

articles.description: A new study has paved the way for the first drug treatment for sleep apnea. Compared to before receiving the treatment, breathing pauses decreased with on average more than 20 per hour for patients given the drug.
articles.title: Drug reduced frequency of breathing pauses in sleep apnea

articles.description: The general availability of Defender for APIs, a new offering as part of Microsoft Defender for Cloud, that helps organizations prevent, detect, and respond to API threats with an integrated cloud security context.
articles.title: Announcing General Availability of Microsoft Defender for APIs

articles.description: Users can now build application logic in Azure Function apps which can be driven by the data from Azure SQL database.
articles.title: GA: Azure SQL Trigger for Azure Functions

articles.description: You can now develop Azure Functions locally on the new Apple Silicon Macs.
articles.title: Generally Available: Azure Functions support on Apple Silicon Macs

articles.description: If you are using VNet injection to secure your Azure Data Explorer (ADX) cluster, you may face some challenges such as complexity, scalability, and public IP dependency. We recommend that you switch to Azure Private Endpoints, which allow you to connect to your cluster privately within your VNet. We have released a preview feature that lets you migrate your VNet injected ADX cluster to Private Endpoints easily and quickly.
articles.title: Migration of Azure Virtual Network injected Azure Data Explorer cluster to Private Endpoints

sources.title: Microsoft Tech Community - Latest Blogs - Apps on Azure Blog

articles.author: AntonioTerra
articles.description:
Welcome to our comprehensive guide dedicated to resolving challenges that arise when Azure App Services encounter difficulties pulling images from the Azure Container Registry (ACR). Deploying applications seamlessly often hinges on a smooth image retrieval process, and encountering obstacles during this phase can disrupt the entire deployment workflow. 
 
In this guide, we'll delve into a step-by-step checklist meticulously designed to diagnose and troubleshoot these issues effectively. From initial authentication, those include Admin Credentials, Managed Identity and access permissions to navigating complex network configurations for both Public and Private ingress on the ACR, this resource aims to be your go-to reference for untangling and resolving image pull issues within the Azure ec…
articles.title: Troubleshooting Guide: Resolving Azure App Services Image Pull Issues from Azure Container Registry

articles.author: Sean_Li
articles.description:
Welcome to the first episode of the Java on Azure Container Apps blog series! In case you missed the introductory episode, you can read it here to get a sense of what it’s about and what you can expect to see in the future.
This blog is based on the Spring Petclinic project with a REST backend and an Angular frontend. The objective is to build and deploy Petclinic on Azure Container Apps and we’ll carry it out in 2 steps:

Build and deploy a Spring REST app to Azure Container Apps directly from the source. 
Package the front-end Angular app in a container first and deploy it to Azure Container Apps.

Build and deploy a Spring app to Azure Container Apps
As a developer, you always want to prioritize retaining the inner loop workflow and developer experience during the coding and testing pha…
articles.title: Java on Azure Container Apps - Build and deploy polyglot apps in two simple steps

articles.author: Calvin_Cai
articles.description:
In this article
    Linux 
        nslookup 
        dig 
        NodeJS 
        Python 
        tcpping 
        curl 
        tcpdump 
    Windows

        tcpping.exe 
        curl.exe 
        Webjob 
For application running on Azure App Service, sometimes the code throwing error to connect to target service due to intermittent connectivity issue.To identify the issue, it's not convenient if we keep modify and deploy the code, we could use App Service Kudu site to do some quick testing and no need to change any code.
Linux
Login to your app service Kudu site, e.g. https://<appname>.scm.azurewebsites.net, and navigate to "SSH" menu. You should be able to see SSH shell.If you are using custom image, then you need enable it by follow document: https://learn.micr…
articles.title: Troubleshoot intermittent connectivity issue in azure app service

articles.author: kevinguo
articles.description:
Further facilitate teamwork in collaboration apps with Large Language Models
Apps like Microsoft Loop, Figma, Notion, Miro, Framer are redefining remote collaboration. 
Beyond hosting the newest and latest version of a file, these modern collaboration apps allow users to make edits to the same file at the same time as if they were physically next to each other.

With the rise of large language models (LLMs) and their increasingly sophisticated capabilities, we’d like to explore how AI can further facilitate teamwork using the aforementioned collaboration applications.  
 
AI agent as another human collaborator
The mainstream way of interacting with a language model is through a familiar chat interface. One characteristic about this interaction that’s relevant to our discussion is that it’s…
articles.title: Supercharge collaboration apps with Large Language Models and Azure SignalR Service

articles.author: thomasgauvinmsft
articles.description:
Welcome to this month’s newsletter.
We round up the latest news, product announcements, content and community highlights – in one compact post.  

View the newsletter archives: https://aka.ms/swa/thismonth  
Catch the community livestream: https://aka.ms/swa/community/standups

Azure Static Web Apps Livestream 
The Community Standups livestream happens on the last Thursday of each month. Join us for the next one for some interactive demo and discussions. 
 
This was our last livestream of 2023, but join us again in January as we kickoff the new year with some announcements. This month we walk through using Static Web Apps to build OpenAI chat applications with retrieval augmented generated responses. Check out past episodes for more exciting demos and guests! 
 
Community Highlights 
Recent Azure Static Web Apps announcements:

Build serverless full-stack .NET 8 applications with Blazor WebAssembly and Azure Static Web Apps

Community highlights:

Combining the powers of Azure SWA and APIs - Poornima Nayar - Copenhagen DevFest 2023 - YouTube (Video)
Azure Static Web Appsを使ってNuxt3サイトをデプロイしてみた #Node.js – Qiita (Blog)
Publish HTML project using Azure Static Web Apps | by Marc Kenneth Lomio & Melrose Mejidana | Nov, 2023 | Medium
A Re-Platforming Journey from Gatsby to Astro (blueboxes.co.uk)

New & updated documentation:

Tutorial: Deploy a React app on Azure Static Web Apps | Microsoft Learn
Tutorial: Deploy an Angular app on Azure Static Web Apps | Microsoft Learn
Tutorial: Deploy a Vue app on Azure Static Web Apps | Microsoft Learn
Deploy a Blazor app on Azure Static Web Apps | Microsoft Learn

 
Upcoming events

Our first community standup of the new year in January 2024, last Thursday of the month! Follow us on Twitter to get notified.
articles.title: This Month In Azure Static Web Apps | November & December 2023

articles.author: Mayunk Jain
articles.description: Since the announcement of the retirement of App Service Environment v1 and v2, we have been encouraged by the velocity with which organizations have begun upgrading to the latest version. If your organization hasn’t yet made the switch, consider this blog a gentle nudge to prioritize your migration to App Service Environment v3 before the Aug. 31, 2024, deadline. As a reminder, starting on Jan. 15, 2024, users will no longer be able to create a new App Service Environment v1 or v2. Even though support for existing v1 or v2 environments will continue until the Aug. 31 deadline, App Service Environment created after Jan 15 will be on version 3. To avoid potential disruptions and ensure the seamless operation of your services, we strongly recommend initiating the migration process without del…
articles.title: The countdown is on! Discover resources to upgrade your App Service Environment today

articles.author: mpgraven
articles.description:
With three big events, November was a month packed with exciting announcements, important product updates, and lots of learning opportunities. For this post, we’re highlighting news and insightful sessions from .NET Conf, Microsoft Ignite, and GitHub Universe.
 
Watch .NET Conf 2023 on demandSessions from .NET Conf are now available to watch on demand. Find out how to create a full stack web UI with Blazor in .NET 8, build intelligent apps, learn GitHub Copilot tips for .NET developers, explore C# 12 features, and much more.
 
Download .NET 8Get started with .NET 8. Download .NET 8 now.
 
What's new in C# 12Watch this session from .NET Conf on demand for a tour of what’s new in C# 12, including collection expressions, primary constructors, and demos of new features.
 
Build intelligent app…
articles.title: Highlights from .NET Conf, Microsoft Ignite, and GitHub Universe

articles.author: naiyuantian
articles.description:
We have just released the preview of a new major version of the Durable Functions extension! 
 
Durable Functions (DF) enables you to write long-running, reliable, event-driven, and stateful logic on the Azure Functions platform using everyday imperative code. 
 
There are two major changes introduced in this release: upgrading to the latest version of the Azure Storage SDK (a breaking change for .NET in-process apps) and the introduction of a new partition manager. We describe these and the motivation for each in the sections below. 
 
Please note: 

At this time, DF extension v3.0.0-rc.1 is only supported in the App Service Plan. Auto-scaling support for the Consumption and Elastic Premium plans will be announced later. 
Durable Functions v3 does not support Azure Functions runtime V1.  …
articles.title: Preview of Durable Functions Extension v3.0.0

articles.author: thomasgauvinmsft
articles.description:
With the release of .NET 8, Blazor has evolved from a client-first web UI framework to a full-stack web UI framework. This announcement introduced new rendering modes and interactivity, allowing more flexibility to choose the right rendering mode for your Blazor web apps. In this article, we’ll take a closer look at standalone Blazor WebAssembly (WASM) projects, their considerations relative to other Blazor rendering modes, and how we can build full-stack .NET 8 serverless apps on Azure Static Web Apps with Blazor WASM and Functions APIs.
 
.NET 8 Blazor rendering modes & hosting considerations
 
In .NET 8, Blazor has introduced a unified full-stack model, the Blazor Web App. This model enables you to opt for any of the various supported rendering modes (client rendering, server-side rende…
articles.title: Build and deploy .NET 8 Blazor WASM apps with serverless APIs using Azure Static Web Apps

articles.author: Sean_Li
articles.description:
Developers love containerization for its ability to ensure consistency, portability and manageability of their applications, while aligning with modern DevOps practices. Azure Container Apps is a great platform for running polyglot apps and containers of all kinds in Azure, as it abstracts away the complexity of managing underlying Kubernetes while providing unified networking, observability, and scaling for higher developer velocity. While it serves as a versatile container platform, it may not offer precise insights into your Java applications or the state of your Java execution environment (such as the JVM). To better cater to our Java-centric customers running containerized apps, we've recently initiated a new journey to enhance the Java developer experience on Azure Container Apps.
 
…
articles.title: Running Java applications on Azure Container Apps

articles.author: SaloniAgrawal12
articles.description:
The enchantment of AI has cast its spell on us, urging us to include it further into our daily lives. In the software industry, a significant chunk of our efforts revolves around discovering ways to optimize code and enhance system performance. If only AI could lend a hand in this process—well, your wish is our command!
 
Riding the AI wave, we present a powerful combination of tools: the Application Insights Profiler, Code Optimizations, and Azure Load Testing, designed to unveil bottlenecks within your code when your application is grappling with heavy load.
 
This blog will walk you through steps to obtain these code-level suggestions to improve your system’s performance.
 
Application Insights Profiler       
Application Insights Profiler is a feature in Azure Monitor that helps you ca…
articles.title: Unleashing Code-Level Improvements with Azure Load Testing and AI

articles.author: KenTao0903
articles.description: If you are a Spring developer and maintaining some Spring apps for your company, upgrading to the new Spring version should be a regular task for you. While upgrading to the latest versions of Spring Boot and JDK is a monumental step forward, bringing substantial performance improvements and new features to enjoy, it’s a fact that this leap can pose significant challenges and demand substantial effort from developers. Typically, open-source Spring project minor releases receive support for a minimum of 12 months from the date of initial release, and then making sure upgrading the Spring version timely before reaching the end-of-life date is a hard commitment to avoid putting your mission-critical workloads at risk. Now with VMware Tanzu Spring Runtime Support naturally built in Azure Sprin…
articles.title: Extended Support for Spring Boot 2 Projects in Azure Spring Apps Enterprise

articles.author: Youna_Hyun
articles.description:
When developing a function, it is imperative to thoroughly test the code on multiple occasions. Utilizing the Code+Test feature in the portal provides a straightforward method for testing, where you can simply click the "Run" button.
 
If your function is configured to be accessible from the public network, testing on your local PC is a viable option. However, in the scenario where the private endpoint is enabled within your function app, attempting to test may result in a 403 error accompanied by an error message.
Error message: You must have direct network access in order to run your function. Your app may be restricted with Private Endpoints, Access Restrictions or Service Endpoints.

 
Why did I get the 403 status code?
As you are aware, a private endpoint imposes restrictions on publi…
articles.title: How to execute Code+Test when a private endpoint is enabled?

articles.author: kevinguo
articles.description:
TL; DR
Socket.IO library is natively supported on Azure. Since we public previewed this feature, we received positive feedback from users. Now we are happy to share that Web PubSub for Socket.IO is generally available, which means that Azure customers can expect stable APIs, SLAs customer support and it’s suitable for use in production.
 
Solve the scalability issue without code rewrite.
When we interviewed Socket.IO users, the challenge of scaling out Socket.IO servers came up repeatedly. It’s a challenge that can be met uniquely by Azure. With the input from Socket.IO users, it’s a challenge we aimed to solve when we public previewed the support for Socket.IO on Azure two months ago. 
 
Developers can continue using the Socket.IO APIs they know and love and migrate to Azure seamless with…
articles.title: Azure Web PubSub for Socket.IO is now generally available

articles.author: Marina_Liu
articles.description:
For configuring customized notification of function app, Application Insight alter with custom log search is a suitable way to achieve the goal.
In this blog, I will take two senarios (function invocation is under long time running and function fails due to timeout) as examples for how to set the customized notifications. Below is one situation which might need customized notification:
Function invocations' time duration might span with a wide range (such as function which handles uploaded files whose size might be a few KB or more than tens GB), notification is needed if a function invocation persists for a long time or it fails with timeout.
 
Detailed steps for creating a customized notification as below:

 
Step 1: Create Alert rule
First, please go to the Application Insight which is …
articles.title: Configure customized notification for Function App
